title: Report: 'Alternate' NFL cheerleaders aren't treated any better than regular ones

author: nanook
title: LeBron James to RETIRE after NBA Finals: Stunning claim from veteran Jason Terry
summary: GETTY LeBron James has been tipped to retire if he wins the NBA Finals James is hoping to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to their second title in four years when they kick-off their Finals against Golden State Warriors in the early hours of Friday morning. It is the fourth consecutive year that the two teams have met at the business end of the season. James has an incredible postseason record with an average of 34 points per game - but Terry thinks he could retire on a high should he win basketball's top prize. The 33-year-old is in his 15th season in NBA and becomes a free agent following the Finals. This might be it for him Jason Terry And Terry, who is the guard for Milwaukee Bucks, thinks this

title: Usain Bolt won't get his 9th gold medal back, spoiling his perfect record

title: Zinedine Zidane abruptly resigns as Real Madrid manager
summary: Zinedine Zidane won three Champions League titles in two-and-a-half seasons at Real Madrid, but says the club "needs a change."

author: captainunderoos
title: UNC Walked After Massive Cheating. NCCU Makes A Mistake And Gets Hammered
summary: So just to be clear about this...UNC cheats for nearly 20 years, screws hundreds of athletes out of a potentially life-changing education, is put on probation by the accreditation agency ...and the NCAA can do nothing. However, NCCU makes some unintentional mistakes, some players played while ineligible and the school self-reported...and gets hammered. In Central's case, 58 games were forfeited between baseball, football and basketball, the school is on probation for two years and has to pay $5,000 dollars. So here's a question: if Central's athletes were ineligible and events had to be forfeited, and UNC played with athletes who were enrolled in frankly fraudulent classes, why are their competitions

title: Why MLB needs to strike now on Shohei Ohtani's stardom
summary: Simply put, MLB needs to figure how to make Ohtani's arrival in any city buzz-worthy, can't-miss action.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Position-by-position matchups for the NBA Finals. Who has the edge?
summary: A position-by-position look at the matchups in the NBA Finals between the Golden State Warriors and Cleveland Cavaliers: CENTER Kevon Looney vs. Tristan Thompson. An afterthought much of the season, Thompson rejoined the Cleveland rotation in the playoffs and has provided the Cavaliers with 6.1 points and 6.1 rebounds per game. Warriors coach Steve Kerr went with Looney against Houston but could go a number of ways in this series, with JaVale McGee, Zaza Pachulia and Jordan Bell among his options. And of course, the Warriors are at their best when they go with none of the above, using Draymond Green as the center in a small-ball lineup. Edge: Warriors. POWER FORWARD Draymond Green vs. Kevin Love

title: Cardinals TE Jermaine Gresham picks up unexpected bag fee for stranded traveler
summary: Cardinals tight end Jermaine Gresham saw a traveler in need on Wednesday and offered a small gesture that made a big difference in her day.

author: ipostwhaticareabout
title: Phillies OF Rhys Hoskins has broken jaw after fouling fastball into his own face
summary: A Wednesday CAT scan reportedly revealed that Rhys Hoskins broke his jaw when he fouled a ball into his face on Monday, an injury he pinch-hit with on Tuesday.

author: third_watch
title: NBA Finals: Bob Myers aware that Warriors' championship run will not last forever
summary: OAKLAND – The road to the NBA Finals has not changed for four years. The Warriors arrived here with a front office, coaching staff and All-Star players collaborating for the common good. The Cleveland Cavaliers arrived here with LeBron James prevailing through roster turnover and front-office dysfunction. Will it ever change? The rest of the NBA wishes that already had happened. The Warriors and Cavaliers hope it keeps going. And for Warriors general manager Bob Myers, he dreadfully sees an expiration date approaching. “I definitely know this is ending,” Myers said Wednesday on the eve of Game 1. “I don't need any reminders. The narrative is, 'This will go on forever.' On the record, it can't.

author: DeltaBravo
title: Scandal-tainted Brian Bowen opts to stay in NBA draft

author: nanook
title: NBA Finals: Gary Payton says all-time best not LeBron or Jordan
summary: OAKLAND — Don't ask Gary Payton to wade in on the LeBron James vs. Michael Jordan debate. “Me, I think Wilt Chamberlain and Kareem (Abdul-Jabbar) are the two best basketball players ever,” Payton said Wednesday during NBA Finals media day. “Wilt Chamberlain, by far, is my best basketball player. Best athlete ever.” Chamberlain averaged a record 50.4 points per game in 1961-62, and Abdul-Jabbar remains the NBA's career scoring leader. Payton said James' performances stand on their own and don't need to be measured against what Jordan achieved. “I don't compare them — different eras. He has his era, Michael had his era. You've got two players who dominated their eras,” said the Hall of Fame guard,

title: Southwest apologizes after Cal coach says airline asked her to prove that biracial son was hers

author: rocky.j.mountain
title: Brandon Ingram is the Lakers' X-Factor
summary: When watching Brandon Ingram play for the Los Angeles Lakers over his first two years in the league so far, the first thing that jumps off the screen — other than that he never seems to change expressions — is that Ingram is a physical freak. Ingram isn't a superstar yet, and he may never be, but regardless of what one thinks of his game, it's almost inarguable that he has the best natural tools of any members of the Lakers' current young core. Likewise, the ceilings for other members of the Lakers' young core also appear pretty clear, because we've seen players like them. Kyle Kuzma is probably going to be a very good scoring forward, while Josh Hart is a three-and-D guy with maybe a little more off-the-dribble skill than most of that ilk.
